data.title: South China Sea
data.meta_description: News about South China Sea, including commentary and archival articles published in The New York Times.
data.text:
Why China’s and Russia’s Militaries Are Training Together

The two countries have held joint exercises near Alaska, Taiwan and Japan in defiance of the United States and its alliances.

By David Pierson

Thitu Island Dispatch

The Filipinos Living in the Shadow of China’s Military Might

More than 200 civilian settlers on a contested island in the South China Sea find themselves on the frontier of a possible conflict with China.

By Camille Elemia and Jes Aznar

Why Are There Fears of War in the South China Sea?

China claims most of the strategic waterway and is trying to push out neighbors like the Philippines. Any deadly mistake could risk war.

By Mike Ives

U.S. Pledges $500 Million in New Military Aid to the Philippines, as China Asserts Sea Claims

Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III warned Beijing against engaging in hostilities with U.S. allies in the South and East China Seas.

By Edward Wong

What to Know About Kamala Harris’s Foreign Policy Positions

Here is what we know about the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee’s views on issues like migration and the wars in Ukraine and Gaza.

By Eve Sampson

Guest Essay

Beijing Can Take the South China Sea Without Firing a Shot

The United States needs to start standing up to Chinese aggression in this vital waterway.

By Oriana Skylar Mastro

The Chinese Base That Isn’t There

Before and after satellite images show how China transformed one Cambodian navy base.

By Agnes Chang and Hannah Beech

News analysis

Putin Came to Asia to Disrupt, and He Succeeded

His embrace of North Korea and deal making with Vietnam injected more potential threats into a region already strained by Taiwan tensions and South China Sea clashes.

By Damien Cave

In Singapore, China Warns U.S. While Zelensky Seeks Support

The annual Shangri-La Dialogue became a stage for competing demands on U.S. global power, including the war in Ukraine and tensions over Taiwan.

By Chris Buckley and Damien Cave
